Painful NostalgiaMy teacher gave me this book when I left for America and I'm honestly surprised and so in love with it. This story at its core is a coming of age story, we follow Chuong, a city boy who has to spend the summer in the countryside of Vietnam with his aunt and cousins. Over the course of this book, the protagonist runs into some misfits, have some small adventures, and learn some important life lessons, there is an element of romance as well. Now for me, the book hits me really hard because I can relate so much to it, it reminded of my life before I had to move to America, at the end of the book I almost teared up because it gave me so much nostalgia and when I closed it I was just left with an empty feeling. Overall, I recommend it. Now I'm going to go into more details so spoilers I guess. As much as I love the book I don't really like Chuong, from the start of the book to halfway through I didn't really like him, he can sometimes be stupid, immature, and bratty but it's a coming of age story so at the end you do see him acting more mature. It's not only a coming of age story but also a story about young love, while Chuong is enjoying his summer he met a soft-spoken girl named Them, Chuong, of course, fell for her but it seems very one-sided. Because of this romance element that also contributed to the feeling of emptiness and sorrow at the end of the book for me. Them is engaged to someone else already, this revelation hit Chuong like a truck, but instead of acting selfish or just being childish he just put on a smile, gave her a goodbye gift and go back to the busy city. This just made my heart sank, I was speechless, so I just put the book down and just sat for a while as so many emotions were rushing through me. I truly felt empty.
